elements.name: section_cs_school
elements.html: <h1>Computer Science Courses Currently Offered at Your School

elements.name: section_cs_school_intro
elements.html:
We would like to know about Computer Science courses currently offered at your school.

Please refer to this definition of Computer Science courses to answer the questions in this survey:

Computer Science focuses on understanding why and how computers work. Students study the impact of technology on society, and aims to develop coding and hardware and software design skills.

Computer Science courses do not aim to teach students how to use computers or computer applications like word processing software.

elements.name: cs_offering
elements.title: In my school, computer science courses are currently offered to students in grades 9-12. (Check one.)

elements.name: available_courses
elements.title: Which of the following computer science courses are available to students in this school? (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: AP Computer Science A
AP Computer Science Principles
IB Computer Science Standard Level
IB Computer Science Higher Level
Other IB computer science course
Concurrent college and high school credit/dual enrollment computer science courses
Another computer science course that includes programming but does not qualify for college credit

elements.name: contents_cs_course
elements.title: What content is covered in computer science courses at your school (from introductory to advanced)? (Check all that apply.)

choices.text: Ethical and social issues in computing
Logic applications in IT and IS

elements.name: take_cs_programming
elements.title: Can students at your school get credit by taking computer science courses that teach programming through any of these other options? (Check all that apply.)

choices.text: From a teacher in this school
Through virtual courses offered by other schools/institutions (e.g., online, videoconference)
By going to a Career and Technical Education (CTE) center
By going to another high school
By going to a college or university

elements.noneText: Grades 9-12 students in this school cannot take a computer science course that teaches programming or requires programming as a prerequisite

elements.name: number_students
elements.title: Approximately how many students in grades 9-12 in this school will take a computer science course this year that includes programming or has programming as a prerequisite? (Please enter a number.)
elements.requiredErrorText: Please enter a number greater than 0.
elements.minErrorText: Please enter a number greater than 0.

elements.name: grad_requirement
elements.title: In order to graduate from this high school, how many years of computer science are grades 9-12 students required to take? (Check one.)

elements.name: count_toward_requirement
elements.title: Can computer science courses count towards students' high school graduation requirements in each of the following subject areas? (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: Mathematics
Science
Foreign Language

elements.name: section_APCS_plans
elements.html: <h1>Details on Offering AP Computer Science Principles at Your School

elements.name: section_APCS_plans_intro
elements.html: <h3>Please share more details about your plans for offering AP Computer Science Principles courses.

elements.name: grade_levels_csp
elements.title: In my school, AP Computer Science Principles is or will be taught to students in the following grade levels. (Check all that apply.)

elements.name: required_course_status
elements.title: Is AP Computer Science Principles (or will it be) offered as a required or elective course at your school? (Check one.)

elements.name: csp_prerequisites
elements.title: Does AP Computer Science Principles have (or will it have) prerequisites or other entrance criteria at your school? (Check one.)

choices.text: Yes, it will have prerequisites and/or entrance criteria
No, it will be open to all students

elements.name: section_time_minutes
elements.title: On average, how many MINUTES PER WEEK does (or will) a typical section of AP Computer Science Principles meet? (Check one.)

elements.name: course_length_weeks
elements.title: Approximately how many WEEKS does (or will) a typical section of AP Computer Science Principles run? (Check one.)

elements.name: section_cs_resources
elements.html: <h1>Resources for Computer Science at Your School

elements.name: section_cs_resources_intro
elements.html: <h3> We would like to better understand resources available for Computer Science education at your school.

elements.name: student_interest_achievement
elements.title: Indicate whether your school does each of the following to enhance students' interests and/or achievement in computer science. (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: Holds family computer science nights
Offers after-school help in computer science (e.g., tutoring)
Offers formal after-school programs for enrichment in computer science
Offers one or more computer science clubs
Participates in Hour of Code
Participates in a local or regional computer science fair
Has one or more teams participating in computer science competitions (e.g., USA Computer Science Olympiad)
Encourages students to participate in computer science summer programs or camps offered by community colleges, universities, museums, or computer science centers
Coordinates visits to business, industry, and/or research sites related to computer science
Coordinates meeting with adult mentors who work in computer science fields
Coordinates internships in computer science fields

elements.name: school_facilities_1
elements.title: Do you have the resources you need to set up a computer science section?

elements.name: school_facilities_2
elements.title: Which resources are scarce? (Check all that apply.)

elements.name: school_facilities_3
elements.title: In your school, are multiple computer science courses taught in the same room simultaneously? (Check one.)

elements.name: school_facilities_4
elements.title: Does your school have… (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: One or more computer labs available for teachers to schedule for their classes?
Laptop/table carts available for teachers to use with their classes?
A 1-to-1 initiative (every students is provided with a laptop or tablet)?
School-wide Wi-Fi?

elements.name: student_device_policy
elements.title: Which of the following best describes your school's policy about students using their own computing devices in classes? (Check one.)

choices.text: Students are required to provide their own laptops or tablet for use in classes
Students are not required but are allowed to bring their own laptops or tablets for use in classes
Students are not allowed to use their own laptops or tablets in classes

elements.name: pd_workshops
elements.title: In the last three years, has your school and/or district offered teacher professional development WORKSHOPS specifically focused on computer science or computer science teaching, possibly in conjunction with other organizations (e.g., other school districts/dioceses, college or universities, museums, professional associations, commercial vendors)? (Check one.)

elements.name: pd_teacher_study_groups
elements.title: In the last three years, has your school and/or district offered teacher STUDY GROUPS where teachers meet on a regular basis to discuss teaching and learning of computer science, and possibly other content areas as well (sometimes referred to as Professional Learning Communities, PLCs, or lesson study)? (Check one.)

elements.name: pd_one_on_one_coaching
elements.title: Do any teachers in your school have access to one-on-one coaching focused on improving their computer science instruction (including voluntary and/or required coaching)? (Check one.)

elements.name: section_cs_community_intro
elements.html: We would like to better understand resources and supports available in your educational community, as well as perceptions about Computer Science.

elements.name: cs_community
elements.title: How much do you agree or disagree with the following statements about your computer science educational community? (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: When I need help around administering computer science courses, I have someone to turn to
I know computer science leaders and role models in my community
I feel like I'm part of a broad computer science education movement
I am excited to collaborate with computer science leaders in my community
I see my code.org representative as a resource and support for computer science education in my community

elements.name: cs_community_important
elements.title: How much to you agree or disagree with the following statements about the leaders and community members around you? (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: I tell others in our school about the benefits of offering introductory computer science for students
Counselors at my school communicate the benefits of computer science to all students
Families here think offering computer science is important
Community leaders (political leaders, clergy, other) here think offering computer science courses is important
Other local stakeholders (businesses, higher education, other) here think offering computer science courses is important
There is student demand for more computer science courses in my school

elements.name: resistance_change
elements.title: What do you perceive to be the greatest challenges in offering computer science courses in your school? (Check all that apply.)

elements.name: section_cs_beliefs
elements.html: <h1>What Should Computer Science Look Like in Your School?

elements.name: section_cs_beliefs_intro
elements.html: <h3>We would like to know your thoughts on what Computer Science teaching should look like in your school.

elements.name: pairs_of_statements_instructions
elements.html: Please read statements A and B below and select a value on the 1-5 rating scale below the statements that represents how your personal beliefs or philosophy align to one statement or the other.

elements.name: recruit_responsibility
elements.html:
Statement A Statement B
Administrators have a responsibility to recruit a set of students into their classrooms that are representative of the school’s population in terms of diversity (gender, racial, socio-economic, etc.) Administrators’ responsibility is to promote their computer science classes broadly, to all students. The diversity of the class will reflect those most interested in taking a computer science class.

elements.name: cs_4_all_1
elements.title: To what extent does your school counselor(s) do each of the following. (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: Help students from all backgrounds (e.g., honors students, students with disabilities, English-language learners) understand what computer science is
Help students from all backgrounds understand where computer science may fit into their future
Give the same amount of consideration to placing students into computer science courses as into other disciplines
Encourage students who are typically under-represented in computer science courses (e.g., girls, students of color) to enroll in computer science courses

elements.name: cs_4_all_2
elements.title: How important is it for teachers to engage in each of the following practices in their computer science instruction? (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: Develop all students’ awareness of computing careers
Provide computer science instruction that is based on students’ interests in and ideas about the topics you teach
Use formative assessment to monitor student learning
Differentiate computer science instruction to meet the needs of diverse learners
Incorporate students’ cultural backgrounds into computer science instruction
Encourage interest in computer science among students of all backgrounds (e.g., honors students, students with disabilities, English-language learners)
Encourage participation of all students, especially those traditionally underrepresented in computer science (e.g., females, racial/ethnic minorities, students from low socioeconomic backgrounds)

elements.name: cs_classroom_1
elements.title: How important is it for teachers to use each of the following instructional strategies in their computer science instruction? (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: Explain computer science ideas to the whole class
Engage the whole class in discussions
Have students work in small groups
Engage the class in project-based learning (PBL) activities
Have the class work independently on individual computers
Have students make formal presentations to the rest of the class (e.g., on individual or group projects)
Do hands-on activities off the computer (e.g., making diagrams, organizing ideas with post-its, "unplugged" activities that involve manipulatives and/or physical movement)

elements.name: cs_classroom_2
elements.title: How much do you agree or disagree with the following statements about what good computer science courses are like? (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: Students learn science best in classes with students of similar abilities
Teachers should explain an idea to students before having them consider evidence that relates to the idea
Most class periods should include some review of previously covered ideas and skills
Most class periods should provide opportunities for students to share their thinking and reasoning
Hands-on activities should be used primarily to reinforce a computer science idea that the students have already learned
Students should have choice in designing computer science curriculum and learning activities
Teachers should connect students’ prior knowledge with computer science concepts for deeper learning
Teachers should incorporate a variety of teaching methods in computer science to help students be successful

elements.name: cs_4_all_3
elements.title: How much support do your teachers need to do each of the following in their computer science instruction? (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: Plan instruction so students at different levels of achievement can increase their understanding of the ideas targeted in each activity
Teach computer science to students who have learning disabilities
Teach computer science to students who have physical disabilities
Teach computer science to English-language learners
Provide enrichment experiences for students identified as Gifted and Talented
Manage classroom discipline

elements.name: cog_demand_cs
elements.title: How much do you agree or disagree with the following statements about computer science? Learning computer science can help students learn how to… (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: Consider alternative approaches to their work
Analyze (organize, process, manipulate, evaluate) data
Explain the logic and reasoning supporting their solutions
Communicate their thought processes to others
Problem solve when something doesn’t work the way they want it to work
Persist when schoolwork is difficult

elements.name: value_skills_cs
elements.title: How much do you agree or disagree with the following statements about computer science? Learning computer science can help… (Check one in each row.)

rows.text: Develop students’ math skills
Develop students’ science skills
Develop students’ literacy skills
Students communicate their thought processes to others
Develop students’ digital citizenship skills

elements.name: section_demographics_intro
elements.html: <h3>This last set of questions gather demographic information for reporting purposes.

elements.title: How many years have you been working in K-12 schools? (Please enter a number.)
elements.requiredErrorText: Please enter a number greater than 0.24.
elements.minErrorText: Please enter a number greater than 0.24.

elements.requiredErrorText: Please enter a number greater than 0.24.
elements.minErrorText: Please enter a number greater than 0.24.
elements.maxErrorText: Wow, do you really have that many years of experience? Please check your answer.

elements.name: general_ed_level
elements.title: What is the highest educational degree you have earned? (Check one.)

choices.text: Doctoral or Professional Degree (PhD, EdD, MD, JD, etc.)

elements.name: highest_level_cs_education

choices.text: I took/am taking one or more courses online for credit
I took/am taking one or more courses in college
I am currently in the process of earning a computer science certificate
I am currently in the process of earning a computer science degree
I have a certificate in computer science
I have a Bachelor's degree in computer science
I have a Master's degree in computer science
I have a PhD in computer science

elements.noneText: At this time, I have little to no formal education in computer science

elements.title: Please list the computer science certifications or endorsements you have and/or are working toward:

elements.name: cs_background_pd
elements.title: How much professional development on  computer science did you have before participating in the Code.org professional development sessions? (Check one.)

elements.minErrorText: Are you really over 90 years old! Wow! Just enter 1911.
elements.maxErrorText: Are you really younger than a 22-year-old school admin? Just enter 1999.
